body:
eLearning helps you reach people that you would never be able to reach in a classroom alone. However, eLearning is much more than putting learning online. Uploading powerpoints and talking heads from classroom lectures will not facilitate quality learning.

In this module we explore the following:

  • Refining your audience and topic
  • Designing your outcomes and structure
  • Including content and case studies
  • Refining your style
  • Writing questions
title: Writing eLearning

body: While open data in the Caribbean is still in its early stages of adoption, momentum has been steadily building among key stakeholders in the region. Below are some examples of how open data is helping agriculture in the Caribbean.
title: Case studies from the Caribbean

_items.title: HarvestAPI
_items.body:
Where: Jamaica.

Who: SlashRoots Foundation and the Rural Agricultural Development Authority.

What: HarvestAPI is an open source platform that publishes agricultural data across government agencies and with the public. The platform is being developed to increase access to the Government of Jamaica Farmer register. 

Why: Opening up data catalyses innovation in the sector and, in the process, helps overcome some of the structural challenges that limit the access, use and maintenance of quality agricultural data.

Take me to the HarvestAPI website

_items.title: Jamaica Agricultural Marketing Information System (JAMIS)
_items.body:
Where: Jamaica.

Who: The Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Information Division & RADA.

What: A service that provides unbiased data on farm gates, markets, and wholesale and retail prices on a weekly basis.

Why: To provide accurate and unbiased marketing information depicting current trade conditions. The aim is to promote orderly marketing and enhance competition. 

Take me to the JAMIS website

_items.title: AgriNeTT
_items.body:
Where: Trinidad and Tobago.

Who: The University of the West Indies in collaboration with industry experts.

What: An open data repository, containing datasets from institutions and associations. Datasets included are farm-level production data; commodity prices and volumes; farm land spatial data; soils data; weather data; and pest and diseases tracking data.

Why: For local developers to visualise the data and build applications that are useful to the community. 

Take me to the AgriNeTT website

_items.title: CIRP-mFisheries
_items.body:
Where: Trinidad and Tobago.

Who: The Caribbean ICT Research Programme.

What: A suite of mobile applications designed to improve market conditions, efficiency and safety for small-scale fisherfolk in Trinidad and Tobago.

Why: The government has prioritised development in the fishing industry on account of its economic and social significance. It aims to make this sector competitive, sustainable and profitable, as well as inclusive, equitable and supportive of the local fishing communities. 

Take me to the mFisheries website

_items.title: National Agricultural Market Information System (NAMIS)
_items.body:
Where: Trinidad and Tobago.

Who: The National Agricultural Marketing and Development Corporation.

What: NAMIS publishes buyer and exporter information, as well as price, volume and production data.

Why: To stimulate investments in the agri-food sector by providing data for making strategic, investment, management and policy decisions by all stakeholders.

Take me to the NAMIS website

body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:
title: What makes data open?

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way.

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

body: And as the world’s population grows from 7.4 billion to potentially 10 billion by 2050, the agricultural system will play a key role in ensuring our global demands can be met. Open data could be a key driver in improving the agricultural sector worldwide. In the Caribbean, there is huge potential to use open data to solve problems, improve processes and drive innovation within agriculture.
displayTitle: The benefits of open data for agriculture
title: The benefits of open data for agriculture
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: Increasing efficiency
_items.body:
Open data can improve the efficiency of logistics and make processes much more streamlined. 

Jamaica often suffers from coordination problems both in times of drought and of plenty. Open data platforms, which match demand and supply, can streamline crop production and planning. 

Access to consumption, production and crop maturity data can also enable policy-makers to make data-driven decisions on whether to increase or decrease local production and how much to export.

Enhanced access to geospatial and meteorological data helps farmers make better decisions about where and when to plant for the maximum yield, and how changes in weather patterns might affect crops. 

Using open data to drive mobile applications can also provide on-demand access to agricultural data from individuals and governments, supporting farmers working on the fields.

_items.title: Increasing transparency
_items.body:
Open data has the power to increase transparency in the agricultural sector.

Open access to procurement data can help ensure that procurement processes have been followed and best value tools and products have been invested in.

Open access to supply data can help to ensure that farmers get competitive prices for farming tools and products.

Open data can also help reduce decrease praedial larceny (theft of agricultural produce or livestock) in the Caribbean, which poses a huge threat to the sector.

Collecting and analysing open theft data will allow authorities to identify where in the production chain the thefts occur, and improve attempts to prevent them.

_items.title: Driving innovation
_items.body:
Publishing official open government agriculture data enables technical developers and domain experts to innovate and create products and services which boost the agriculture ecosystem.

Small startup ventures such as Agrocentral and HarvestAPI have started using agriculture price and production data produced by the Caribbean Ministry of Agriculture.

Other organisations, such as the Climate Corporation, have leveraged climate and soil open data to develop insurance products which help farmers protect and improve their farming operations, raising over $100m in venture capital.

_items.title: Enhancing collaboration
_items.body:
Studies currently estimate that only 30% of food purchased by Jamaican hotels is locally sourced. Opening supply and demand data improves collaboration between agriculture and key demand sectors such as tourism.

Crowdsourcing the collection of data can lead to increased availability and improved accuracy of open data. Encouraging farmers and other agricultural end-users to participate in the data collection or the verification process will increase data quality as well as quantity.

The government agency Rural Agricultural Development Authority (RADA), has collaborated with technology innovator Slashroots to create a platform for publishing and sharing of agricultural sector data across government and with the public.

body:
Agribusiness is the business of agricultural production.

Agribusiness consists of industry, commerce and trade. Industry includes the production of commodities and materials. Commerce and trade refer to the distribution of those commodities and materials.

In the Caribbean, agribusiness is essential, with agriculture contributing 15.6% to Dominica's GDP, 7.6% to St Vincent and the Grenadines' GDP and 7.4% to Jamaica's GDP in 2015 (source: World Bank). All these figures are lower than they were in 1995.
title: What is agribusiness?

body:
Agribusinesses boost the economy, contribute to domestic food supply and provide employment.

Taking the country of Jamaica: despite falling between 1995 and 2007, the contribution of agriculture to Jamaica’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has risen by 2.1% to 7.4% between 2007 and 2015.

Food exports from the island increased by 22.3%, moving from US$224 million in 2011 to US$274 million in 2012.

Jamaica agribusinesses produce a variety agricultural commodities for export. These include Tin Ackee, Callaloo, hot pepper sauce, Pickapeppa sauce, rum, beer, coffee products, Scotch Bonnet Pepper, Jerk BBQ Sauce, sugar, yam and sweet potato.

The sector currently employs 18% of the national workforce in Jamaica.
displayTitle: Why is agribusiness essential to the Caribbean?
title: Why is agribusiness essential to the Caribbean?

body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived. 

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. 

Using open data in agriculture will make processes more efficient and target decision making, which can improve crop yield, promote collaboration across the sector, and create new business and services.

However, open data is only valuable where it is being used. Some organisations and projects in the Caribbean are making huge steps towards improving agriculture with open data. To harness open data's full potential, and to get actors across the production chain sharing and using key datasets, the sector needs to adopt a culture that uses, produces and embraces data.

For more information on open data and agriculture, take a look at How can we improve agriculture, food and nutrition with open data? published by the Open Data Institute and GODAN.

Agriculture is a major industry in the Caribbean. However in recent years the industry has reduced in size and value, not just in the Caribbean but worldwide.

Agribusiness - the business of agriculture - is essential to reduce this declining trend. Agribusinesses boost the economy, contribute to domestic food supply and provide employment.

Agribusinesses can be split into three sectors: input, production and output. These three sectors cover all stages of the process, from 'pre-farm' to fork.

Given their size and importance in the Caribbean, agriculture and agribusinesses need to be constantly evolving. New technology, data, regulations and an ever increasing threat of food security both challenge and provide new opportunities to those working in the sector.

body:
Questions are a useful way for learners to test their learning. Not every eLearning module has to include questions, but it is recommended.

When designing questions, take another look at your outcomes and your structure. You should generally have a question per block which should align to an outcome. There are times when you can combine two blocks into one question.

Make sure that the answer to the question is in the block that that question relates to. Using the same text is fine, as for learning repetition is key. The aim of eLearning is for your learners to learn, not for you to trick them with complex questions and multiple answers.

In Adapt you can give learners feedback. Using the same text as appears in the original learning will help them to remember the answer, even if they got the question wrong.

Repeating the picture that you used in the original block will also help visual learners.
title: Writing questions

body: Agribusiness is a complex industry with many moving parts. There are three key sectors: input, production and output.
displayTitle: What are the sectors in agribusiness?
title: What are the sectors in agribusiness?
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: 1. Input
_items.body:
The input sector of agribusiness includes all resources involved in producing farm commodities.

Sometimes referred to as 'pre-farm', the input sector includes manufacturers of products such as plant seed, fertilisers, animal feed, machinery, fuel and chemicals.

Examples of input agribusinesses firms in Jamaica include Newport Fersan Chemicals, manufacturer and distributor of fertiliser and H&L AGRO (previously AgroGrace)

_items.title: 2. Production
_items.body:
Production is a key sector of agribusiness.

It includes groups such as farmers, fresh produce growers, companies producing seafood or growing trees and even ornamental plant producers.

The Jamaica Broilers Group is an example of one of the largest production agribusiness firms in the Caribbean.

_items.title: 3. Output
_items.body:
The output sector of agribusiness includes all services that link producers and consumers, from farm to fork.

This includes transportation, storage, packaging, inspections and sales, as well as the post-harvest processing of meat, fish and fruit and vegetables.

In Jamaica, the Marketing Extension Unit of the Rural Agricultural Development Agency (RADA) runs programs to assist farmers in the output sector.

The main roles of the unit are:

  • Assisting farmers with production planning for market sources
  • Assisting farmers with identifying and implementing appropriate marketing strategies for specific market sources
  • Training farmers and middlemen in post harvest handling of produce
  • Training farmers to operate in groups
  • Linking farmers with wholesalers, and retailers, supermarkets, green groceries, hotels and any other food-purchasing enterprises.

body: As such an important sector for the Caribbean and the world, agriculture needs to be constantly evolving. Below are five trends to watch as according to AgWeb.
title: Trends to watch
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: New technology
_items.body:
From farm to fork, new technology is rapidly changing the way the agricultural sector works.

From drip irrigation to precision agriculture, 'smart farms' could save producers' money, increase the efficiency in operations and increase crop yields.

The International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) have built an interactive tool where you can see the effects of 11 new technologies on farms.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is playing an increasingly important role in many sectors, and agriculture is no exception.

From geospatial data, to food safety data; from land use data to market data, there are many valuable datasets to enrich the activities of agribusinesses.

Data can make agribusinesses more efficient, increase transparency of their operations (see regulations block below), drive innovation and enhance collaboration.

For more information about data and agriculture, take a look at this module.

_items.title: Biologicals
_items.body:
Across the sector, there is a shift from chemical to biological products in the fight against weeds, insects and diseases.

Controlling pests with biological products differs from chemical products and will require a different mindset.

A shift from chemical to biological products will also have an effect on companies who supply these products.

_items.title: Regulations
_items.body:
Agribusinesses are under increasing pressure to provide evidence of origin for their products and commodities. 

For some in the supply chain, this means an enormous overhaul of the way their operations are run.

Sharing supply chain data between suppliers is one way in which agribusinesses can be certain of the origin of their products and commodities. Publishing that data as open data would mean that consumers were equally certain.

_items.title: Food security
_items.body:
The world needs to produce at least 50% more food to feed 9 billion people by 2050. But climate change and changing landscapes could reduce crop yields by more than a quarter. 

Unless we change how we grow our food, food security—especially for the world’s poorest—will be at risk.

Many governments, NGOs and businesses are tackling the issue of food security, although they need the support of those on the ground - across input, production and output agribusinesses - to succeed.

body: Agriculture is a data-intensive sector. The access to, analysis and use of timely and accurate data about environmental conditions, production, market logistics and pricing, has become essential for the sector worldwide.
displayTitle: What is data, and why is it useful?
title: What is data, and why is it useful?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Data can be quantities, characters and symbols. It can come in the form of images, descriptions, reviews, prices or anything else that could form the basis of information. 

For example, the number of banana trees growing in farms across a parish, recorded in a spreadsheet, is data. The number of trees is the data, and the spreadsheet that holds the data is the dataset.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

For example, in comparing the number of banana trees to the geographical location of the farms, it might be deduced that banana production is greater in the eastern parishes than in the western parishes.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information and personalized for your needs. Information turns to knowledge when you are able to make informed decisions or choices.

For example, drawing on information that banana production is greater in the eastern parishes region, the Producers group that manufactures snack foods from bananas might choose to focus their sourcing partnerships with farmers in the eastern parishes.

The first thing you need to decide is your audience. This may be given to you in a brief by a client, or you may need to define your audience yourself. Think about what your audience wants or needs to learn about. It can be useful to write a concept note to help you answer some key questions.

With learning, less can be more. You might find that your topic is too broad to fit into one module and would be better split into multiple modules. The adapt framework lets you link modules together.
title: Refining your audience and topic

body: Every individual has his or her own style of designing and delivering learning. Below, we explore some ways to avoid some common traps and create a suitable environment for your learners to learn at their own pace.
title: Refining your style
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: Avoid complex language
_items.body:
The aim of writing eLearning is to create a suitable environment for your learners to learn at their own pace.

It should not be a chance for you to demonstrate sophisticated writing techniques, complex language or complicated sentence structures.

Using easy words and short sentences will help your learners learn the key information and will ensure they aren't distracted by added noise.

_items.title: Define key terms
_items.body:
Key terms are concepts that will be used throughout the eLearning. 

It is important to make sure that learners can define the key terms at the beginning of any lesson, whether online or in the classroom. They will be unable to successfully continue their learning if they cannot define the basic concepts.

Often, the first outcome in an eLearning module will be for learners to define key terms. For example, the first block in this open data and agriculture module is devoted to defining data and open data.

However, not all concepts are important for learners. Once again, ask yourself what your learners need to learn in order to complete the module. Try to avoid too many complex terms, as people can only learn x in x, and you don't want them to remember complex concepts and nothing else!

_items.title: Repetition
_items.body:
Most types of writing require the writer to use synonyms to vary the language and terms used in the text. 

For learning, repetition is key. Repetition reinforces learning and makes key information stay at the forefront of the learner's mind.

Try to avoid synonyms, particularly for your key terms. Very few words mean exactly the same thing. For example, you could argue that the 'value of open data' and the 'impact of open data' are synonymous and yet they have slightly different meanings.

_items.title: Look and feel
_items.body: Using pictures can be a great way to help reinforce learning, particularly for visual learners. Engaging visuals that are related to the content will help learners. However, pictures can also be distracting, particularly if they are unrelated, jarring or offensive. Try to be consistent with the pictures that you use within a module.

body: Contrary to popular belief, the next stage of designing learning is not writing the content, but designing the structure. Planning the structure and outcomes of your learning makes it easier to check that your content has a logical flow.
title: Designing your outcomes and structure
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: Outcomes
_items.body:
Outcome-led learning is where you identify what your learners need to learn before you start. These are commonly called learning outcomes or learning objectives.

Content-led learning (learning where the content is decided before the structure or outcome) leads to surface learning. Outcome led learning leads to deep learning. To find out more about these concepts and how they relate to levels of teaching, take a look at this video.

Writing outcomes can be quite challenging at the beginning. Try to think of them as the headings that you want.

List the headings at the beginning to guide your learners -  these can be framed as questions, or simply as bullet points.

_items.title: Structure
_items.body:
You should include the outcomes you've written in the bullet points at the beginning of each module. Your structure should signpost your learners and let them know what they are going to learn next.

Each outcome should match to a block and a question.

Each block should build on the last. You can think of it like steps to reach a goal.

body:
Once the structure and outcomes are in place, the next thing to look at is the content itself. The content needs to be relevant to both the audience and the topic, so keep both in mind when you're writing. 

Content needs to match the block heading and the tick at the top (the outcome). Make sure that you include the key information that you want them to learn

Be strict with yourself: if the content doesn't match the headings and/or the ticks, take another look at the structure. It might be that the structure needs refining, but it also might be that the content doesn't have a logical flow. This is also known as alignment. For many people, alignment is the most challenging part of designing learning and it can be frustrating to realise that what you have designed isn't working because it isn't aligned.

Including relevant case studies and examples to back up your content will help your learners. Adult learners in particular need to be able to see how what they are learning is relevant to them and their work. One great thing about online learning is that you can hyperlink to the examples and case studies that you've used, so that your learners can verify what they are learning. Including links is also good for 'deep learners' who want to take their learning to the next level and explore more in the subject area.
title: Including content and case studies

body:
Adapt has a hierarchical layout consisting of pages, articles, blocks and components.

Taking the lead from modern web design, these objects form scrolling pages that present information in a responsible and cross device compatible way allowing people to learn with just a swipe of a finger or thumb.
title: The ABC of Adapt

_items.title: Pages
_items.body: Pages are how the main learning content is presented (similar to a page on the web), and can contain a number of sub-elements, making them perfect to present a single topic in an eLearning course.

_items.title: Articles
_items.body:
Articles are the next step down, and are used to present compound pieces of information within the page. Like pages, articles can be formed of many sub-elements. Articles can also be used to split up a page for presentation purposes.

Typically articles are used to split an assessment section from the main content.

This page contains three articles (all labelled). Although an article can have a title and content, it is advisable to keep all content in components only, leaving articles and blocks to manage layout and style.

_items.title: Blocks
_items.body:
Blocks have replaced the traditional screens/slides found in most eLearning publishing software, and present small chunks of related content using components.

In this block (labelled) we have two components (an accordion and a graphic). The block keeps the two together, maintaining the relation. 

Here the block also has a style applied to take a background colour in order to clearly divide the different blocks.

_items.title: Components
_items.body:
Components are the main interactions in Adapt, and present simple ideas. Components can be used in a block full-width, or combined with another component for more variety.

Find out more about all the different components, including question components via the Adapt 2.0 demonstration. 

You can also develop your own bespoke components by following the component development guide.

body:
In order to get started with building courses in Adapt it is highly recommended that an instance of the authoring tool is setup and supported with regular updates.

A guide on how to set up the authoring tool can be found here.

There are also providers of commercial instances of the authoring tool if you don't want to set up your own instance. 

Once you are setup with the authoring tool you can use this to graphically create courses containing pages, articles, blocks and components.
title: Adapt authoring tool

body:
The majority of courses developed in Adapt eLearning will consist of multiple pages (modules) that form one course. By default the authoring tool will use the default theme and the box menu to give learners a clear way to navigate throughout the course. You can of course customise these with your own menu design and theme, however this needs to be done in code. 

If you wish to develop a course with a single page (or disable the menu) then you can use the start controller, available from the project settings menu of a course.
title: Structuring a course

body:
Adapt comes with a default (Vanilla) theme as used on the demo site which also has a customisation guide. 

The Open Data Institute (in collaboration with SpongeUK) developed a custom theme for the Caribbean Open Institute that makes blocks stand out and allows quick setting of colors of blocks and components. This theme is also fully responsive to mobile devices and screen widths. If you can, resize this module to see how it responds and changes the layout of components. 

The source code for the CSD theme can be downloaded (as a zip) from the ODI's GitHub. You can then upload the theme directly into the authoring tool using the plugin manager. 

The theme contains 10 color classes "color-one" to "color-ten" which when applied to the class field in the settings of a block will apply that color to the block component parts. If you wish the block background to be the color specified with content in white then add the "inverted" class as well as the color. The theme contains a color palette picture for reference as well as a README with more instructions. 

In this course we have used color-one and color-two with every other block inverted.
title: Using themes

body:
By default, the download button in the authoring tool will export a version of the course which can be simply hosted on a web server for people to access.

However extensions can be used to make this exported object into a SCORM 1.2 compliant object for importing into a Learning Management System (LMS). Extensions also add key functionality to your course. 

Explore the different extensions below:
title: Deploying your course

_items.title: Page Level Progress
_items.body:
This page allows uses to get a visual indication of their progress through a page as well as provide a fast navigation path on a page. 

Not that this extension is enabled by default on all components. We recommend only leaving it enabled for components that have titles.

_items.title: Tutor
_items.body: The tutor extension provides a basic feedback overlay for question components. Without it the feedback simply won't show.

_items.title: Trickle
_items.body: Trickle is a vertical locking extension which prevents the learning from scrolling until all the previous components are complete.

_items.title: Bookmarking
_items.body: Enables the user to resume from their last known point when they reload/restart the learning.

_items.title: Spoor
_items.body:
This is the core SCORM extension that enables the output of SCORM 1.2 compliant learning objects.

The SCORM 1.2 standard is a widely adopted standard for tracking of a users learning within a Learning Management System. While some aspects of SCORM are mandatory, different LMS platforms require different configurations of the SCORM plugin.

In order to successful deploy the SCORM plugin will involve the input of the LMS administrator to specify the required and supported configuration in Adapt.

_items.title: Assessment
_items.body:
An extension which attaches to an article object to group various question components and provide a score with feedback.

If you are expecting your LMS to receive an attainment score then you will need to enable this extension and configure it for every article in our course that contains an assessment.

body:
The following parts of the Adapt eLearning framework can be customised with user contributed plugins and versions:

  • Menus
  • Themes
  • Extensions
  • Components

There is a community plugin registry where plugins can be simply downloaded from and added to the authoring tool. 

Additionally you can choose to develop your own plugins following the many guides available on the wiki.

To find out more about the Adapt framework and authoring tool developments and roadmaps you can refer to their respective open Github repositories.
title: Adapt plugins

body:
The Adapt community is a open community. All their source code, roadmaps and latest developments are open. This means that you get complete visibility on the tool and its future. 

Additionally you can connect to the community in many ways:
title: Getting help

_items.title: The Adapt wiki
_items.body: The Adapt wiki is the most up to date place to find documentation and general guides.

_items.title: Adapt source code
_items.body:
A key part of the plugins in adapt is the associated documentation. Each plugin will have it's own associate Github repository which will contain a README.md to help you find out about how to use and configure each. 

For example:

  • Accordion component
  • Graphical multiple choice question

Additionally you can find out the latest developments in each plugin this way.

_items.title: Adapt forum and mailing list
_items.body: The adapt community forums and mailing lists are a great way to get help and find answers to questions that might have already been asked.

_items.title: Developers discussion channels
_items.body:
The core developers of Adapt use the open Gitter platform for discussing and managing the roadmap. 

If you are wanting to expand the core or develop a specific plugin you can find them online here.

body: In which of the presentation elements of Adapt should you place your main learning content?
title: Q: The ABC of Adapt

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Components should contain the main learning content (text and images) to be displayed to your learner. Articles and blocks are used to arrange the learning into logical sequences.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Components should contain the main learning content (text and images) to be displayed to your learner. Articles and blocks are used to arrange the learning into logical sequences.

body: When using the ODI designed theme for the Caribbean Open Institute, which presentation element in Adapt do you add the “color-ten” style to in order to change the colour of presented content?
title: Q: Using themes

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Blocks are like the slides in a presentation. However as Adapt provides an infinite scroll experience, colouring blocks different colours helps break up content as slides do.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Blocks are like the slides in a presentation. However as Adapt provides an infinite scroll experience, coloring blocks different colors helps break up content as slides do.

body: If you wish to deploy your course inside a SCORM compliant Learning Management System which two extensions need to be added to your course?
title: Q: Deploying your course

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

To make an engaging course you might need them all, however Spoor is essential for deployment in a SCORM compliant Learning Management System (LMS). Assessment is required if your course contains questions of which you want the learners score reported to the LMS.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

To make an engaging course you might need them all, however Spoor is essential for deployment in a SCORM compliant Learning Management System (LMS). Assessment is required if your course contains questions of which you want the learners score reported to the LMS.

body: Which of the follow are parts of the Adapt framework that can be customised with plugins?
title: Q: Adapt plugins
instruction: Select all answers you think are correct and press 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

All the key visual elements (menus, themes and components) can be custom designed as plugins. In addition extensions, including reporting extensions like Spoor, are also plugins allowing the customisation of a course's behaviour.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

All the key visual elements (menus, themes and components) can be custom designed as plugins. In addition extensions, including reporting extensions like Spoor, are also plugins allowing the customisation of a course's behaviour.

body:
At the end of each page, it is useful to include a summary. This should be where you draw out key messages again.

In the COI theme add the classes 'inverted footer' to the block in order to turn it the dark grey. Again this separates it visually from the rest of the content.

So there we have it. Get to know your ABC (of Adapt) and you too can create great courses. The biggest challenge is getting the content right so that learners learn.

To finish, the footer below is also part of the theme, ensuring it is included on every page.
title: Summary
